This Agreement is made between the Sultan of Muscat and Oman (hereinafter called w the Sultanate”) of the one part, and Basil Woods-Ballard, M.B.E., an officer at present on leave pending retirement from the I.P.S (hereinafter called ”the officer”) of the other part. Whereas the Sultanate has engaged the officer to serve the Sultanate in the capacity for the terms and the pay hereinafter mentioned. Now these presents witness ana the parties hereto respectively agree as follows 1. The Officer will serve the Sultanate for a period of two years from the date of his reporting for duty in Muscat. He will serve the Sultanate in the capacity of “Nadhir Al-Khrijiyyah” (Minister of Foreign Affairs), taking full charge of the duties and responsibilities attached to the post and which may entrusted to him by the Sultanate. 2. The Officer shall devote his whole time to the duties of his appointment as mentioned in clause 1 hereof and shall not engage directly or indirectly in any trade, business or occupation on his account. 3. The salary of the Officer shall be Rs. 2,500 per mensem free of Sultanate tax, provided that he shall be paid at the rate of Rs. 1,250 per mensem free of Sultanate tax, from the 1st October 1948 until such time as he reports for duty in Muscat alter the completion of a three months' course in Arabic. 4. The Sultanate will provide the Officer and his wife with iirst class passages by sea from England to Muscat and back to England in a similar fashion at the commencement and termination the contract. Provided that the Officer's wife may avail herself of her free passages at any time from ana includingthe day on which her husband leaves England to report for duty in Muscat after the completion of his Arabic studies. 5. The Sultanate shall also meet any responsible expenditure incurred by the officer in sending luggage by sea to and from Muscat and not exceeding £10 on each ocaassion. 6. The Sultanate shall provide the officer and his wife with suitable free plainly furnished accommodation. 7. During the hot weather the officer shall be granted recess at Karachi for a period of six weeks. Provided that if the officer agrees to fly both ways this recess may, with the agreement of the Sultanate, be taken in the United Kingdom. Provided further that no additional cost of passage on travelling shall be incurred by the Sultanate than if the officer had recessed in Karachi. Such recesses shall be taken between the months of April and October. For the purpose of such recesses the Sultanate shall bear the cost of one first class passage and one deck passage from Muscat to Karachi and return. During such recess the officer shall be granted 14 days' 'station leave'. Such leave shall not count against the privilege leave mentioned in the next succeeding clause. 8. The officer shall be entitled to privilege leave on full pay for a period calculated at the rate of one month's leave to 12 months' service. Such leave shall be accumulative and the officer shall be entitled thereto at the completion of two years service or by arrangement with the Sultanate. 9. The officer shall be entitled to sick leave in Muscat for such period as the officer may be certified by competent Medical Authority as being unable to perform his duties hereunder. 10. The officer shall be entitled to free transport and actual expense when travelling, on duty. 11. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 19; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. A previous foliation sequence between ff 5-18, which is also circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: Continuing on from the previous file (IOR/R/15/6/276), this file concerns the appointment of the Minister for Foreign Affairs for Muscat. The correspondence mainly concerns travel expenses for the newly appointed Basil Woods Ballard's journey from London to Muscat, via Bahrain. Also discussed is Woods Ballad's contract of employment. The file's principal correspondents are the following: the Political Agent and Consul, Muscat; the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf; the Foreign Office; the Sultan of Muscat and Oman [Sa‘īd bin Taymūr Āl Bū Sa‘īd].
